title: What's the difference between a 61 and 88 keyboard? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is a HUGE difference! A 61 keyboard doesn’t have as many keys, 27 to be precise, as an 88 keyboard. This means that when you play more difficult pieces that span higher registers, with a 61 keyboard, you literally can’t play the piece. I honestly don’t really understand why keyboards with less than 88 keys are a thing, and why so many people buy them. Keyboards are technically sort of a cheaper version of the piano. This means they’re made to resemble the piano, and having less keys is like utterly defeating the purpose of how it’s supposed to be like a piano. When I was younger, I got a keyboard that had around 50 something keys. I tried it a few times and then it went into the basement storage. The keyboard pissed my off so much because I literally couldn’t play my piano pieces on it. Hmm, a B octave chord that goes into the lower two octaves? Can’t play it, too low. An arpeggio going into a high C in the upper three octaves? Can’t play that either. 27 keys may not seem like a lot, but that is more than 3 octaves that the keyboard doesn’t have. There is such a huge, drastic difference between 61 and 88 keyboards.

27 more keys!Seriously, piano music is written for pianos with 88 keys, and even though you don’t always use all of them, there are frequently situations where you need the keys that a 61-key keyboard doesn’t have. If you play jazz, you will enjoy the full keyboard perhaps even more. A full 88-key keyboard provides space for full expression of musical ideas. Whenever I have to play a short keyboard; even one with 76 keys, I find it to be a frustrating experience as I naturally reach for keys that aren’t there. It is something like two people sleeping in a twin-size bed!
